posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
Mastodon supports link verification, which allows users to quickly verify the account is controlled by who they claim to be.
So for example, when I see that @fsf@hostux.social has the link fsf.org verified, I can know for sure that the account and the domain are controlled by the same person/organisation (in this case, the FSF).

Screenshot 2022-12-27 at 17.26.551148√ó466 27.5 KB

Signal, on the other hand, don‚Äôt have a verified link on their Mastodon account. This means that without having prior knowledge that this is the official account, users have to trust this account is not controlled by someone else.

Screenshot 2022-12-27 at 17.29.301150√ó538 45.5 KB

The verification process is quite simple - it essentially only requires that Signal add a single link to their Mastodon profile with a rel=me on the official website. There‚Äôs even the perfect spot for it to go in:

Screenshot 2022-12-27 at 17.34.291254√ó364 30.4 KB

I think this is worth the (in my view, very minor) effort, and it would show that Signal take their Mastodon account somewhat seriously.

posts.cooked: Last toot on Mastodon from Signal I see is from 19. of January‚Ä¶
And their account was never verified, so I‚Äôm having doubts about its legitimacy‚Ä¶

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked: It is legitimate (they posted it on their other official accounts), but they definitely don‚Äôt put much effort into it.

Hello, Mastodon - signalapp@mastodon.world

Edit: should have posted this after Miscellaneous tweets by Signal - #44 by ponytail (4 Nov 2022)

posts.name: Bansh≈ç Ten'in
posts.cooked: As expected for most people and even tech companies, it was just the stuff of the moment to hop on for the ‚Äúanti Elon‚Äù trend. But in the end they realized the numbers are on Twitter, not on mastodon. Even tho posting on both wouldnt require that much effort.

Yes, it was driven by ‚Äúanti Elon‚Äù. And yes, most people still on twitter. But as long as they have this official mastodon account I would expect to ‚Äúhear‚Äù a toot there for each tweet on twitter. I also guess this should not be too much effort.

posts.name: (he/him)
posts.cooked: especially with, for example, Buffer recently adding Mastodon compatibility.

posts.name: link ‚ú¶
posts.cooked:
They‚Äôve just recently added:

<link href=https://mastodon.world/@signalapp rel=me>

to signal.org so:

1142√ó272 9.65 KB

They‚Äôve not added a visible link to their Mastodon on the website, though.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
huzzah!
though I must admit I am confused about the link not being visible. why not boast it?
